title: `spack activate` ignores machine architecture in package matching
body:
### Expected Result
```
# on an x86 machine
$ spack install py-flake8    # hash = 12345

# on a ppc64le machine
$ spack install py-flake8    # hash = abcde

# Then...

# on an x86 machine
$ spack activate py-flake8
==> Activated extension [...] /12345

# on a ppc64le machine
$ spack activate py-flake8
==> Activated extension [...] /abcde
```

### Actual Result

```
$ spack activate py-flake8@3.5.0
==> Error: py-flake8@3.5.0 matches multiple packages.
  Matching packages:
    db63xz7 py-flake8@3.5.0%gcc@4.9.3 arch=linux-rhel7-ppc64le
    hvd627q py-flake8@3.5.0%gcc@4.9.3 arch=linux-rhel7-x86_64
```

The problem is only one of these is valid for the spack currently in use. I think spack should be aware of that, to some degree.

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Install 2 python packages -- 1 on ppc64le, 1 on x86 -- to the same spack_root.
(This should be a problem across os versions too, eg linux-rhel7-x86_64 vs linux-rhel6-x86_64, though I haven't actually checked.)

### Information on your system

1 ppc64le box, 1 x86 box, with spack_root pointing to the same NFS directory.
